questions.name: Lifecycle
questions.tooltip: If you have data from at least one life-cycle, please select "Yes."
questions.questionbody: Has your program completed at least one full iteration or life-cycle?

questions.name: Reporting Time Frame
questions.tooltip: Time period for which you are Please indicate the program cycle on which you will be reporting. Please only report on a full set of completed results within a 12-month (or less) time period. If you would like to report on results over a longer time period than 12 months, please contact our team at help@impactgenome.org for guidance.
questions.questionbody: Time period for which you are reporting:

questions.name: Operating Location
questions.tooltip: This is typically where your beneficiaries are located. If you are unsure how to answer, please contact us at help@impactgenome.org for assistance.
questions.questionbody: Where does your program operate?

questions.name: Targeted Outcomes
questions.tooltip: The Impact Genome outcomes are an evidence-based set of common goals or objectives that social impact organizations endeavor to achieve. If you feel that one or more of your program's outcomes is missing, please note that below.
questions.questionbody: Identify the outcome(s) your program aims to produce. (select all that apply)

outcome.name: Access to Temporary Housing
outcome.display: Access to Temporary Housing - The attainment of temporary shelter (e.g., access to a homeless shelter).
outcome.definition: This outcome is satisfied if an individual, who has experienced homelessness, has achieved all of the following within the past year: - Attained access to a temporary shelter (i.e., a homeless shelter) - Attained mental and physical health benefits through access to shelter
outcome.description: The attainment of temporary shelter (e.g., access to a homeless shelter).

outcome.name: Personal Well-Being
outcome.display: Personal Well-Being - The establishment of a support system that improves mental well-being, physical fitness, and financial independence.​
outcome.definition: This outcome is satisfied if an individual, who has experienced homelessness, has achieved all of the following:  - Established a support system that improves mental well-being (e.g., decreased perception of stigma, anxiety, depression, etc.) - Established a support system that improves physical fitness (e.g., increased strength, balance, flexibility, etc.) - Established financial independence (e.g., sustained employment, wage growth, etc.)
outcome.description: The establishment of a support system that improves mental well-being, physical fitness, and financial independence.​

outcome.name: Business and Enterprise Development
outcome.display: Business and Enterprise Development - The attainment of the skills, knowledge and access to resources necessary to grow a micro-enterprise
outcome.definition: This outcome is satisfied if an individual has achieved all of the following within the past year: - Demonstrated entrepreneurship skills, business knowledge and use of best practices - Attained access to resources to improve the business - Achieved financial stability and growth through increased business productivity, revenues, profits, assets or resources
outcome.description: The attainment of the skills, knowledge and access to resources necessary to grow a micro-enterprise

questions.tooltip: Programs can have many types of impact. Please choose the one goal that best represents the primary purpose of your program over 12 months. Any other outcome will be considered a “secondary” outcome for your program. You will have a chance to provide results for all outcomes (primary and secondary) later in the survey.
questions.questionbody: The Impact Genome outcomes are an evidence-based set of common goals or objectives that social impact organizations endeavor to achieve. If you feel that one or more of your program's outcomes is missing, please note that below.

outcome.name: Personal Well-Being
outcome.display: Personal Well-Being - The establishment of a support system that improves mental well-being, physical fitness, and financial independence.​
outcome.definition: This outcome is satisfied if an individual, who has experienced homelessness, has achieved all of the following:  - Established a support system that improves mental well-being (e.g., decreased perception of stigma, anxiety, depression, etc.) - Established a support system that improves physical fitness (e.g., increased strength, balance, flexibility, etc.) - Established financial independence (e.g., sustained employment, wage growth, etc.)

outcome.definition: This outcome is satisfied if an individual has achieved all of the following within the past year: - Demonstrated entrepreneurship skills, business knowledge and use of best practices - Attained access to resources to improve the business - Achieved financial stability and growth through increased business productivity, revenues, profits, assets or resources
outcome.description: The attainment of the skills, knowledge and access to resources necessary to grow a micro-enterprise

outcome.display: Access to Temporary Housing - The attainment of temporary shelter (e.g., access to a homeless shelter).

outcome.description: The attainment of temporary shelter (e.g., access to a homeless shelter).

questions.questionbody: If you have input into the outcomes, or if there are outcomes your program achieves that you feel were not represented, please share your thoughts.

questions.name: technology exclusive
questions.tooltip: If your program is primarily delivered in person, but follow-up is provided via app or website, or if your program is delivered both in person and via technology, select "no."
questions.questionbody: Is your program delivered exclusively via technology? An example would be a program that is delivered using an app or website.

questions.name: dosage

inputdata.text: At least 30 minutes, but less than 1 hour
At least 1 hour, but less than 3 hours
At least 3 hours, but less than 6 hours
At least 6 hours, but less than 12 hours
At least 12 hours, but less than 24 hours

questions.questionbody: Dosage is the length of an individual session or interaction

questions.name: frequency
questions.questionbody: Frequency is how often someone engages with the program.

inputdata.text: At least 1 week, but less than 1 month
At least 1 month, but less than 3 months
At least 3 months, but less than 6 months
At least 6 months, but less than 9 months
At least 9 months, but less than 1 year
At least 1 year, but less than 3 years

questions.questionbody: Duration is the length of one program cycle.
questions.questionhtml: What is the duration of the involvement in your program for a typical beneficiary? (i.e., the length of one program cycle)?

subsections.name: Core Components

questions.name: activities
questions.tooltip: Below you will find a list of common program components associated with your area of work. We provide this list so that you can give a more standardized, detailed explanation of your program’s design. These core components are evidence-based and are designed to be universal and comprehensive. Note: we don't necessarily endorse these components.
questions.questionbody: Help us understand the core components of your program that drive it’s impact.

responsevalue.label: 1 - Incidental to our program design.
responsevalue.genename: Provides instruction in communication skills, such as listening skills and empathy, non-verbal communication, constructive feedback, persuasion, and others

questions.name: activities feedback
questions.questionbody: If you have input into the list of components, please share your thoughts.

subsections.instructions:
Below you will find a list of common program components associated with your area of work. We provide this list so that you can give a more standardized, detailed explanation of your program's design. These core components are evidence-based and are designed to be universal and comprehensive. Note: we don't necessarily endorse these components.

Using a 1 - 5 scale, please score how important each core component is to the success of your program:

  • Not part of this program: this is not present in our program
  • 1: this is only incidental to our program and its success
  • 5: this is critical to our program and its success

Note: most programs only have a handful of components that rate as a 5 on this scale.

questions.name: HOUSING Beneficiary Housing Status
questions.tooltip: If you do not have specific percentages readily available, please enter your best approximation.

inputdata.text: Imminent Risk of Literal Homelessness (within 14 days) - Current housing (or available alternative housing) is safe - Must leave current housing or institution (e.g., hospital, jail) within 14 days - Does not have other housing options, financial resources, and/or support networks to maintain or obtain a safe place to stay after the next 14 days

At-risk of Literal Homelessness (15 - 60 days) - Current housing (or available alternative housing) is safe - Must leave current housing or institution (e.g., hospital, jail) within 15-60 days - Does not have other housing options, financial resources, and/or support networks to maintain or obtain a safe place to stay after the next 15-60 days

Unstably Housed - Current housing (or available alternative housing) is safe - May have to leave current housing or institution in the foreseeable future – within 90 days - Has other housing options, financial resources, and/or support networks to maintain or obtain a safe place to stay
Stably Housed - Current housing (or available alternative housing) is safe - Current housing is stable for the foreseeable future

questions.questionbody: What percentage of your program’s participants are:

option.text: At-risk of Literal Homelessness (15 - 60 days) - Current housing (or available alternative housing) is safe - Must leave current housing or institution (e.g., hospital, jail) within 15-60 days - Does not have other housing options, financial resources, and/or support networks to maintain or obtain a safe place to stay after the next 15-60 days

questions.name: Supporting Evidence location
questions.tooltip: Please write in third-person as this response will appear on your Impact Genome® Scorecard.
questions.questionbody: Describe how you calculated or estimated the number of achieved outcomes, including: - the data point(s) that your calculation/estimation is based on - how you interpreted those data points - source of those data points
questions.questionhtml:
Describe how you calculated or estimated the number of achieved outcomes, including:
  • the data point(s) that your calculation/estimation is based on
  • how you interpreted those data points
  • source of those data points

questions.name: Types of Evidence
questions.tooltip: If you are unsure, please provide your best guess or reach out to help@impactgenome.org to discuss. Also, our team will review your response and will reach out if we have any recommendations.

inputdata.text: Anecdotal evidence or indirect measurement - Testimonials or case studies from participants, or estimates of effectiveness provided by program facilitators
inputdata.content: {"name": "Anecdotal evidence or indirect measurement:", "value": "Testimonials or case studies from participants, or estimates of effectiveness provided by program facilitators"}

inputdata.text: Output metrics - Data that directly quantifies beneficiary participation through measures like attendance rates, students served, workshops held
inputdata.content: {"name": "Output metrics:", "value": "Data that directly quantifies beneficiary participation through measures like attendance rates, students served, workshops held"}

inputdata.text: Point-in-time study - Evidence of success that comes from a study or survey of the program's impact on beneficiaries at a single point in time (i.e. at the end of the program)
inputdata.content: {"name": "Point-in-time study:", "value": "Evidence of success that comes from a study or survey of the program's impact on beneficiaries at a single point in time (i.e. at the end of the program)"}

inputdata.text: Pre-post, cross-sectional, or difference-in-difference study (non-randomized control) -Evidence of success that comes from a study or survey of the program's impact on beneficiaries over a period of time and/or across populations without a randomized control group
inputdata.content: {"name": "Pre-post, cross-sectional, or difference-in-difference study (non-randomized control) :", "value": "Evidence of success that comes from a study or survey of the program's impact on beneficiaries over a period of time and/or across populations without a randomized control group "}

inputdata.text: Randomized control study - Evidence of success that comes from a study or survey of the program's impact on beneficiaries compared to a randomized control group
inputdata.content: {"name": "Randomized control study:", "value": "Evidence of success that comes from a study or survey of the program's impact on beneficiaries compared to a randomized control group"}

questions.name: In-kind Donations
questions.questionbody: Did your program receive in-kind donations?

subquestions.name: In-kind Donations Value
subquestions.tooltip: Estimate the value of the in-kind donations your program received. One way to calculate this is to think about how much your program would have had to spend to pay for these donated goods and services had they not been donated. Your best estimate is fine.

subquestions.name: In-kind Donations Type
subquestions.tooltip: Please provide a brief description of the in-kind donations your program received.

questions.name: Volunteers
questions.questionbody: Did your program utilize volunteers?

subquestions.name: Volunteer Hours
subquestions.tooltip: Estimate the total number of volunteer hours your program utilized. For example, if your program had 10 volunteers who contributed 15 hours each, your response would be 150.

subquestions.name: Volunteer Skill Based
subquestions.tooltip: Examples of skills-based volunteering include lawyers, accountants, consultants, or IT support who are utilizing their specialized skills to assist a program in its operation.
subquestions.questionbody: Percent of volunteer hours that were skills-based.

classification.description: Programs that provide services directly to clients, beneficiaries, or participants

outcome.name: Acquire Full-time, Non-Seasonal Employment
outcome.display: Acquire Full-time, Non-Seasonal Employment - The attainment of full-time, non-seasonal employment and the soft skills to retain the position.
outcome.definition: This outcome is satisfied if an individual has achieved all of the following within the past year: - Demonstrated soft skills necessary to retain employment - Attained full-time, non-seasonal employment and retained it for at least 90 days
outcome.description: The attainment of full-time, non-seasonal employment and the soft skills to retain the position.
